questions.question: Question 1: What is the most common inflammatory myopathy seen in the elderly?
questions.explanation:
The most common inflammatory myopathy seen in elderly patients (>50 years) is inclusion 
body myositis. Inclusion body myositis is a type of inflammatory myopathy. It is characterized by progressive, 
asymmetric muscle weakness most commonly involving the wrist, finger flexors, and quadriceps. 
Muscles of the face and neck may also be involved, presenting as dysphagia. Inclusion body myositis is named so because of the presence of inclusion bodies containing 
amyloid-like protein seen on microscopy.

questions.question:
Question 2: An IT professional complained of weakness of fingers while using the keyboard. It has been 
progressing over the past 2 months. It is more severe on his right hand than his left hand. 
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given history of progressive and predominantly asymmetric muscle weakness is most likely 
suggestive of inclusion body myositis. Inclusion body myositis is a type of inflammatory myopathy. It is seen in people older than 50 
years of age. It is characterized by progressive, asymmetric muscle weakness most commonly 
involving the wrist, finger flexors, and quadriceps. Muscles of the face and neck might also be 
involved, leading to dysphagia. Polymyositis, dermatomyositis, and necrotizing myopathy have predominantly symmetric muscle 
involvement.

questions.question:
Question 3: Patients with which of the following myopathies are generally resistant to 
immunosuppressive therapies?
questions.explanation: Patients with inclusion body myositis are generally resistant to immunosuppressive therapies.

questions.question:
Question 4: Which of the following group of muscles are unlikely to be involved in a patient diagnosed 
with an inflammatory myopathy? 511 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Ocular muscles are unlikely to be involved as they are spared in inflammatory myopathy. They are 
not involved even in advanced, untreated cases. The pattern of muscle involvement in various inflammatory myopathies is: • Proximal muscles are most commonly involved in dermatomyositis and polymyositis, causing 
difficulty in getting up from a chair, brushing hair, etc. • Proximal and distal muscles are involved in inclusion body myositis, such as wrist, finger flexors, 
and quadriceps. 517 
Sold by @itachibot • Pharyngeal and neck-flexor muscles are often involved in all forms of inflammatory myopathy, 
causing dysphagia or difficulty in holding up the head. Respiratory muscles may also be affected 
in advanced cases.

questions.question:
Question 5: Which inflammatory myopathy is most frequently associated with other autoimmune 
diseases?
questions.explanation:
Inflammatory myopathy most frequently associated with other autoimmune diseases is 
polymyositis.

questions.question:
Question 6: A physician is suspecting dermatomyositis in a 27-year-old woman with complaints of 
proximal myalgia and dysphagia. The presence of which of the following signs would be 
pathognomonic of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The presence of Gottron's papules is pathognomonic of dermatomyositis. They are erythematous 
to violaceous papules that occur symmetrically over the extensor aspects of metacarpophalangeal 
and interphalangeal joints. Gottron's sign, on the other hand, is erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such 
as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles. V sign is confluent macular erythema over the lower anterior neck and upper anterior chest. Shawl sign is the confluent macular erythema over the upper back and lateral aspect of arms. All these signs are present in dermatomyositis, but Gottron's papules and heliotrope rash are 
pathognomonic.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 50-year-old woman presented with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up 
from a chair, and combing hair. She is a known case of ovarian cancer. The following finding 
was noted on examination. What is the most probable diagnosis? 512 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image shows upper eyelid lilac erythema or heliotrope rash. The given clinical 
presentation of proximal myopathy with the characteristic heliotrope rash and history of an 
internal malignancy point towards a diagnosis of dermatomyositis. Classic cutaneous signs in dermatomyositis: • Heliotrope rash/ eyelid erythema- violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids. Pathognomonic of 
dermatomyositis. • V sign- confluent macular erythema over the lower anterior neck and upper anterior chest • Shawl sign- confluent macular erythema over the upper back and lateral aspect of arms • Gottron’s papules- erythematous papules and plaques over the extensor surface of the 
metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints. Pathognomonic of dermatomyositis. • Gottron's sign- erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, 
elbows, knees, and ankles • Mechanic’s hands- rough, hyperkeratotic lines on the lateral and palmer areas of the fingers • Scalp erythema and hair loss 518

questions.question:
Question 8: Which of the following would help you to differentiate between dermatomyositis and 
polymyositis in a patient presenting with muscle weakness?
questions.explanation:
An erythematous rash helps in differentiating between the two conditions as it is seen only in 
dermatomyositis. Option A: Elevated levels of creatine kinase are seen in all the inflammatory myopathies. Options B and D: The involvement of proximal muscles more than the distal muscles and 
interstitial lung disease is seen in both polymyositis and dermatomyositis.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 50-year-old woman was recently diagnosed with dermatomyositis. She should be screened 
for which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
This patient should be screened for malignancy as dermatomyositis is often associated with 
underlying malignancies. The most common cancer associated with dermatomyositis is ovarian cancer. Other malignancies 
that are commonly associated with dermatomyositis are: • Breast cancer • Melanoma • Colon cancer • Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma

questions.question:
Question 10: A 30-year-old woman complained of difficulty reaching high cabinets and carrying grocery 
bags. It has been progressing over the past 3 months. Which is the initial investigation of 
choice in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of an inflammatory myositis for which the initial investigation of 
choice is creatine kinase (CK). 522 
Sold by @itachibot Creatine kinase is a marker of muscle breakdown. It is increased in dermatomyositis and 
polymyositis. However, it may be normal in inclusion body myositis. The most specific investigation for inflammatory myositis is a muscle biopsy.

questions.question:
Question 11: A middle-aged woman presented with muscle weakness and pain over her shoulders. On 
examination, the following rash and mechanic's hands were noted. Positive titers of which of 
the following antibodies are associated with her condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and findings of Gottron papules (image) are suggestive of 
dermatomyositis. Positive titers of Anti-Jo-1 (antisynthetase) antibodies are associated with 
interstitial lung disease, arthritis, and mechanic's hands in patients with dermatomyositis. Other autoantibodies seen in dermatomyositis are: • Anti-Mi-2 - highly specific to dermatomyositis • Anti-SRP (anti-signal recognition protein) - associated with severe myositis • Anti–PM-Scl - associated with overlapping myositis and scleroderma • Anti-p155/140 or anti-transcription intermediary factor (TIF)-1 - seen in cancer-associated 
myositis • Anti-MDA5 (anti-CADM 140) - associated with rapidly progressive lung disease and cutaneous 
ulcer

questions.question:
Question 14: A housemaid presents to you with generalized skin thickening and numbness of fingers on 
exposure to cold. She also complains of muscle pain, and difficulty while walking and 
climbing stairs. Investigations reveal the following. The presence of which of the following 
antibodies is diagnostic of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario having features of both systemic sclerosis and dermatomyositis points 
towards a diagnosis of overlap syndrome. The presence of anti-PM/Scl antibodies is diagnostic of 
overlap syndrome. Anti-PM/Scl is a specific antinuclear antibody directed against a nucleolar-protein complex. Overlap syndrome also known as mixed connective tissue disease usually involves a combination 
of three connective tissue diseases: • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) • Progressive systemic sclerosis (PSS) • Polymyositis (PM) or dermatomyositis (DM)

questions.question:
Question 15: A 35-year-old woman presents with severe generalized body ache, fatigue, sleep disturbances, 
and low mood for the past 4 months. On examination, increased pain sensitivity and tender 
bony prominences are noted. Laboratory and radiological investigations are normal. What is 515 
Sold by @itachibot the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The most probable diagnosis for the given clinical scenario is fibromyalgia. Fibromyalgia is characterized by chronic widespread musculoskeletal pain and tenderness 
accompanied by other non-specific somatic symptoms like fatigue and sleep disturbance, for 
>three months. It is more common in females. On examination, they have tenderness in multiple soft tissue 
anatomical locations. Laboratory findings are normal. Patients with fibromyalgia may have an increased prevalence of other syndromes associated with 
pain and fatigue, like chronic headaches, chronic fatigue syndrome, irritable bowel syndrome, 
interstitial cystitis/ painful bladder syndrome, and pelvic pain syndromes. 524 
Sold by @itachibot Options A and B: Polymyositis and dermatomyositis have positive laboratory findings such as 
specific antibodies and radiological findings of multiorgan involvement (ex: interstitial lung 
disease in polymyositis). Option C: Although the given clinical scenario closely resembles clinical depression, the 
examination findings showing tenderness and pain sensitivity favor the diagnosis of fibromyalgia.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following statements is false about fibromyalgia?

options.c: It is associated with HLA B47
options.d: Associated with low serum IgA levels

questions.explanation:
Single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) studies done on fibromyalgia patients 
show hypoperfusion of the thalamus. Fibromyalgia is characterized by chronic widespread musculoskeletal pain and tenderness. It is 
more common in females. Patients with fibromyalgia have an increased prevalence of other syndromes associated with pain 
and fatigue, including chronic fatigue syndrome, chronic headaches, irritable bowel syndrome, 
interstitial cystitis/ painful bladder syndrome, and pelvic pain syndromes. Non-pharmacological treatment strategies for fibromyalgia include physical conditioning and 
aerobic exercise. Opioid analgesics should be avoided in fibromyalgia as they are not effective and 
are associated with opioid-induced hyperalgesia that can worsen both the symptoms and function. 525 
Sold by @itachibot Seronegative Spondyloarthritides
